connections: A chain of islands.
The geography of Japan's archipelago allowed the daimyos to stay in power, seperated and isolated in the regions they controlled.

The various conquered communities under the Devshirme System, like the various islands of the Japanese archipelago under the rule of the shogun, had their empires maintain control over the seperated, controlled parts.
The shogunate addressed various different edicts to the regions of the Japanese archipelago.
The empire that was the Japanese shogunate controlled the various regions of the archipelago.
Japanese feudal society was divided into the various regions owned by the daimyos amongst the Japanese archipelago.
Japan being on an archipelago isolated and protected them from foreigners.
The various islands and people of the archipelago were governed as a single shogunate.
The Japanese shogunate allowed the various islands and regions of the archipelago to become interconnected instead of divided.

The Ottoman Empire took janissaries from other regions to gain and consolidate power, similar to how the various shogunates gained and consolodated power by acquring it from the other shogunates on the archipelago.

Both the Turkish and Japanese empires contained smaller communities under their control, with the Ottoman Empire containing millets, and the Japanese shogunate containing the various daimyos who owned regions of the Japanese archipelago.
Missionaries which traveled to the Japanese archipelago were met with disdain from the Tokugawa Shogunate, which currently controlled the area.
The Mughal Empire controlled regions of the Middle East, while the Tokugawa Shogunate controlled the Japanese archipelago in Asia.
The geography of Japan's archipelago allowed the daimyos to stay in power, seperated and isolated in the regions they controlled.
Powerful landowning nobles in Japan who were loyal to the shogun.

The various conquered communities under the Devshirme System, like the various islands of the Japanese archipelago under the rule of the shogun, had their empires maintain control over the seperated, controlled parts.
A system that required conquered Christian communities to give their sons to the Ottoman government as a form of tax.
The shogunate addressed various different edicts to the regions of the Japanese archipelago.
A command from a government.
The empire that was the Japanese shogunate controlled the various regions of the archipelago.
A group of once separate areas ruled by a single person or government.
Japanese feudal society was divided into the various regions owned by the daimyos amongst the Japanese archipelago.
A decentralized system of power in which land owned by a powerful person is divided up and given to others in exchange for work and a promise to fight for the interest of the land owner.
Japan being on an archipelago isolated and protected them from foreigners.
From another place; unknown.
The various islands and people of the archipelago were governed as a single shogunate.
To rule.
The Japanese shogunate allowed the various islands and regions of the archipelago to become interconnected instead of divided.
The state of having connections or relationships with other people.

The Ottoman Empire took janissaries from other regions to gain and consolidate power, similar to how the various shogunates gained and consolodated power by acquring it from the other shogunates on the archipelago.
A well trained soldier who was taken from his family at a young age and trained to fight for the sultan of the Ottoman Empire and serve him in the government.

Both the Turkish and Japanese empires contained smaller communities under their control, with the Ottoman Empire containing millets, and the Japanese shogunate containing the various daimyos who owned regions of the Japanese archipelago.

Self-governing non-Muslim (Jewish and Christian) communities within the Ottoman Empire that had the power to regulate their own communities, collect taxes, set up their own schools, and organize their own laws.
Missionaries which traveled to the Japanese archipelago were met with disdain from the Tokugawa Shogunate, which currently controlled the area.
A person sent to promote a religion in a foreign place.
The Mughal Empire controlled regions of the Middle East, while the Tokugawa Shogunate controlled the Japanese archipelago in Asia.
A Muslim dynasty [succession of people from one family] that ruled parts of modern-day India and Pakistan from 1526-1857.
A Muslim empire that ruled over parts of Asia, Africa, and Europe from 1299-1922.
A military leader in Japan who had absolute power and passed their power down through their family.
A government ruled by a shogun.
The government that ruled Japan (1600-1868).
A path followed by people who trade with one another.
